thread.title: England rocked by departure of Joe Root as Pakistan edge closer to victory
thread.title_full: England rocked by departure of Joe Root as Pakistan edge closer to victory

title: England rocked by departure of Joe Root as Pakistan edge closer to victory
text:
England rocked by departure of Joe Root as Pakistan edge closer to victory 26 Oct 2015 07:31:57 
comments 
England lost just one wicket in the first hour of day five in Dubai, but it was the key departure of Joe Root as their hopes of salvaging a draw in the second Test faded further. 
Root's presence sowed belief that England could perhaps still bat throughout the day to achieve a stalemate against Pakistan, having been set a notional world-record target of 491 to win. 
Resuming on 130 for three, with Root (71) and Jonny Bairstow batting, they moved to 161 for four by mid-morning. 
Root's was the telling first-innings dismissal on Saturday, the first of seven wickets to fall for 36 runs in the damaging collapse which put England in such trouble here. 
This time, he had passed 3,000 Test runs and was batting serenely until - in the 13th over of the day - Zulfiqar Babar got one in the perfect spot, and turned it enough to take the outside edge on the forward-defence for a low catch at slip. 
Bairstow had already escaped a sharp chance to short-leg, on 11, Shan Masood unable to hold on off the full face of a defensive bat presented to Zulfiqar. 
Meanwhile, England confirmed Alastair Cook has a minor groin injury, but is expected to be fit for the third Test in Sharjah. 
Cook was experiencing obvious pain running between the wickets on Sunday, when assistant coach Paul Farbrace nonetheless insisted there were no concerns about the captain's fitness. Related Sport News
